case_name: Bombay Municipal Corporation v. Widow of P. Nanu Raman

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 133 of 1961 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 29, 1959, of the Bombay High Court in First Appeal No. 317 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 133 of 1961. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 29, 1959, of the Bombay High Court in First Appeal No. 317 of 1958.

facts.text: The Bombay Municipal Corporation runs a public utility transport service in Greater Bombay managed by the Bombay Electricity Supply and Transport Committee.

anchor.surface_text: The Bombay Municipal Corporation, hereinafter called the Corporation, runs a public utility transport service in Greater Bombay and the said transport service is managed by a Committee known as the Bombay Electricity Supply and Transport Committee.

facts.text: P. Nanu Raman was a bus driver employed by the Bombay Municipal Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: One P. Nanu Raman was one of such bus drivers employed by the Corporation.

facts.text: On July 20, 1957, Nanu Raman finished his work at about 7.45 p.m. at Jogeshwari bus depot.

anchor.surface_text: On July 20, 1957, the said Nanu Raman finished his work for the day at about 7.45 p.m. at jogeshwari bus depot.

facts.text: After leaving the bus in the depot, Nanu Raman boarded another bus to go to his residence at Santa Cruz.

anchor.surface_text: After leaving the bus in the depot, he boarded another bus in order to go to his residence at Santa Cruz.

facts.text: The bus collided with a stationary lorry parked at an awkward angle on Ghodbunder Road near Erla Bridge, Andheri.

anchor.surface_text: The said bus collided with a stationary lorry parked at an awkward angle on Ghodbunder Road near Erla Bridge, Andheri.

facts.text: As a result of the collision, Nanu Raman was thrown out on the road and injured.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of the said collision, Nanu Raman was thrown out on the road and injured.

facts.text: Nanu Raman was removed to hospital where he expired on July 26, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: He was removed to hospital for treatment where he expired on July 26, 1957.

facts.text: The respondent, widow of Nanu Raman, filed an application in the Court of the Commissioner for Workmen's Compensation, Bombay, claiming Rs. 3,500 as compensation.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, his widow, filed an application in the Court of the Commissioner for Workmen's Compensation, Bombay, claiming a sum of Rs. 3,500/- as compensation

facts.text: The General Manager of the B.E.S.T. Undertaking was made the respondent and contended that the accident did not arise out of and in the course of the employment of the deceased.

anchor.surface_text: To that application the General Manager of the B.E.S.T. Undertaking, Bombay, was made the respondent, and he contended, inter alia, that the accident did not arise out of and in the course of the employment of the deceased.

facts.text: The Commissioner dismissed the application accepting the contention of the General Manager.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner dismissed the application accepting the contention of the General Manager of the B.E.S.T. Undertaking.

facts.text: On appeal, the Bombay High Court held that the accident arose out of and in the course of the employment and awarded Rs. 3,500 with costs to the widow.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the High Court of Bombay held that the said accident arose out of and in the course of the employment of the said deceased and, on that finding, passed a decree in favour of the widow for a sum of Rs. 3,500/- with costs.

facts.text: Rule 19 of the Standing Rules of the Bombay Municipality B.E.S.T. Undertaking permits a specified number of the traffic outdoor staff in uniform to travel standing in a bus without payment of fares.

anchor.surface_text: Presumably for that reason Rule 19 of the Standing Rules of the Bombay Municipality B.E.S.T. Undertaking permits a specified number of the traffic outdoor staff in uniform to travel standing in a bus without payment of fares.

facts.text: The General Manager of the B.E.S.T. Undertaking preferred the present appeal against the order of the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The General Manager of the B. E. S. T. Undertaking has preferred the present appeal against the order of the High Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on May 10, 1963 by Subba Rao J., with Dayal J. delivering a separate judgment.

anchor.surface_text: 1963. May 10. The Judgment of Subba Rao and Mudholkar.JJ was delivered by Subba Rao J. Dayal J., delivered a separate judgment.

facts.text: The accident to Nanu Raman arose out of and in the course of his employment (majority view).

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, agree with the High Court that the accident occurred to Nanu Raman during the course of his employment and therefore his wife is entitled to compensation.

facts.text: The appeal is dismissed without costs (majority).

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal fails and in the circumstances is dismissed without costs.

facts.text: Dayal J. dissents and would allow the appeal with costs, holding the accident did not arise in the course of employment.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore I would allow the appeal with costs and set aside the order of the court below.

facts.text: Nanu Raman resided at Santa Cruz.

anchor.surface_text: go to his residence at Santa Cruz.

facts.text: Bus drivers have to reach the depot early in the morning and go back home after work.

anchor.surface_text: A bus driver has to drive a bus allotted to him from morning till evening with necessary intervals, and for that purpose he has to reach the depot concerned early in the morning and go back to his home after his work is finished
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 29, 1959, of the Bombay High Court in First Appeal No. 317 of 1958.

Section 3 1 of the Act reads If personal injury is caused to a workman by accident arising out of and in the course of his employment, his employer shall be liable to pay compensation in accordance with the provisions of this Chapter.

issues.text: What is the true construction of s. 3(1) of the Workmen's Compensation Act, 1923, and its application to the facts of this case?

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave raises a short but difficult question of the true construction of s. 3 1 of the Workmens Compensation Act 8 of 1923 , hereinafter called the Act, and its application to the facts of this case. The Bombay Municipal Corporation,

issues.text: Did the death of the husband occur in an accident arising out of and in the course of his employment?

anchor.surface_text: claiming a sum of Rs. 3,500/- as compensation by reason of the death of her husband in an accident alleged to have arisen out of and in the course of his employment. To that application the General Manager of the B.ES.T. Undertaking,

issues.text: Did the accident arise out of and in the course of the employment of the deceased?

anchor.surface_text: and he contended, inter alia, that the accident did not arise out of and in the course of the employment of the deceased. The Commissioner dismissed the application accepting the contention of the General Manager of the

issues.text: Were those injuries caused to him out of and in the course of his employment?

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether those injuries were caused to him out of and in the course of his employment. If the injuries so arose, the appellant Corporation would be liable to pay the compensation.

issues.text: Was this concession by way of a term of his service and a part of the contract of service?

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether this concession was by way of a term of his service and a part of the contract of service. I am of opinion that it was not a part of the contract of service or a condition of his service.

issues.text: Does the free travel concession under Rule 19 extend the course of employment to include travel to and from home on service buses?

anchor.surface_text: Presumably for that reason Rule 19 of the Standing Rules of the Bombay Municipality B.E.S.T. Undertaking permits a specified number of the traffic outdoor staff in uniform to travel standing in a bus without payment of fares.

arguments.claim: The accident did not arise out of and in the course of the employment of the deceased because he had finished his work and had no obligation to travel in the bus which met with the accident, placing him in the same position as any other member of the public.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Pathak, learned counsel for the appellant, contends that the words arising out of and in the course of his employment are pari materia with those found in the corresponding section of the English statute, that the said words have been authoritatively construed by the House of Lords in more than one decision, that an accident happening to an employee in the course of his transit to his house after he left the precincts of his work would be outside the scope of the said words unless he has an obligation under the terms of the contract of service or otherwise to travel in the vehicle meeting with an accident and that in the present case Nanu Raman finished his work and had noobligation to go in the bus which met with the accident and his position was no better than any other member of the public who travelled by the same bus.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: to include such areas over which the employee had, as a matter of necessity, to pass and re-pass. After discussing the facts of the particular case in

arguments.court_reasoning: Implied obligation from Rule 19 and service necessity extends course of employment; not same as public.

arguments.claim: The interpretation of 'arising out of and in the course of his employment' should not be too narrow; there should be an intimate relationship between employment and the accident, and here the deceased had a right under the contract and a duty in a wider sense to travel by the bus as an incident of service.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, Mr. Ganapati Iyer, who was appointed amicus curiae, argued that the interpretation sought to be put on the said words by the appellant was too narrow and that the true interpretation is that there should be an intimate relationship between employment and the accident and that in the present case whether there was a contractual obligation on the part of the deceased to travel by that particular bus or no he had a right to do so under the contract and in the circumstances it was also his duty in a wider sense to do as an incident of his service.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: to include such areas over which the employee had, as a matter of necessity, to pass and re-pass. After discussing the facts of the particular case in

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed, applying wider duty test and implied term from rules and efficiency needs.

arguments.claim: The accident arose out of and in the course of employment per s.3(1) Workmen's Compensation Act, as there is an implied term in the contract of service for free travel via Rule 19, necessary for punctuality and efficiency given Bombay distances.

anchor.surface_text: Presumably for that reason Rule 19 of the Standing Rules of the Bombay Municipality B.E.S.T. Undertaking permits a specified number of the traffic outdoor staff in uniform to travel standing in a bus without payment of fares. Having regard to the long distances to be covered in a city like Bombay, the statutory right conferred under the rule is conducive to the efficiency of the service.

arguments.claim: In Cremins v. Guest, implied term of contract for travel on employer-provided trains extends course of employment.

anchor.surface_text: In Cremins v. Guest, Keen Nettlefolds, Ltd., the Court of Appeal had to deal with a similar problem. Cremins was a collier in the employment of the company. He, along with other employees, lived at Dowlais, six miles from the colliery. A train composed of carriages belonging to the appellants, but driven by the Great Western Railway Company's men, daily conveyed Cremins and many other colliers from Dowlais to a platform at Bedlinog erected by the appellants on land belonging to the said Railway Company.

holdings.text: The accident occurred to Nanu Raman during the course of his employment and therefore his wife is entitled to compensation.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, agree with the High Court that the accident occurred to Nanu Raman during the course of his employment and therefore his wife is entitled to companypensation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Implied term from Rule 19 and necessity for punctuality/efficiency in bus service extends course of employment; entire bus fleet as notional premises; wider duty test applied.

holdings.text: When a driver going home from the depot or coming to the depot uses the bus, any accident that happens to him is an accident in the course of his employment.

anchor.surface_text: We would, therefore, hold that when a driver when going home from the depot or coming to the depot uses the bus, any accident that happens to him is an accident in the course of his employ- ment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Right to free travel under Rule 19 is condition of service for punctuality; adapted notional extension to bus fleet as premises; practical compulsion given distances.

holdings.text: The appeal fails and in the circumstances is dismissed without costs.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal fails and in the circumstances is dismissed without companyts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirming High Court on liability under s.3(1); no challenge to quantum.

holdings.text: The right to travel in the bus in order to discharge his duties punctually and efficiently is a condition of his service.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the right to travel in the bus in order to discharge his duties punctually and efficiently is a condition of his service.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 19 interpreted with service rules emphasizing punctuality; uniform requirement ties to employment status; conducive to efficiency in large city.

holdings.text: Nanu Raman did not die of the injuries received in an accident arising out of and in the course of his employment and therefore the respondent is not entitled to receive any compensation from the appellant under s. 3 of the Workmans Compensation Act 1923.

anchor.surface_text: In view of what I have stated above I hold that Nanu Raman did number die of the injuries received in an accident arising out of and in the course of his employment and that therefore the respondent is number entitled to receive any companypensation from the appellant under s. 3 of the Workmans Compensation Act 1923.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 19 mere concession/privilege with limitations, not term of service; no necessity or obligation; off duty after leaving depot bus; notional extension limited.

holdings.text: This concession was not a part of the contract of service or a condition of his service.

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether this concession was by way of a term of his service and a part of the companytract of service. I am of opinion that it was number a part of the companytract of service or a condition of his service.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 19 limits numbers/seating, applies to others, no tie to duty/punctuality; optional, can pay for seat without uniform.

holdings.text: I would allow the appeal with costs and set aside the order of the court below.
